15 '7 11 Etenim: marks the transition from the general to the particular. The real subiect of the essay begins here. The connection with the preceding part is as follows: Ennius bore cheerfully two things which are commonly considered great burdens—poverty and old age. And old age may be considered a burden with some show of reason, for Ι find four serious indictments commonly brought against it. The con· nection is with putantur onera. The attitude of those who bring these accusations may be compared with that taken by Matthew Arnold in his Growing Old:

What is it to grow old?

Is it to feel our strength— Not our bloom only, but our strength—decay?

Yes, this and more! etc.

Cicero's attitude‚ on the other hand, in various passages throughout the essay, is similar to that of Browning in Rabbi Ben Ezra:

Grow old along with me, The best is yet to be, etc.
